thread.title: Upon further review, it's time to ditch video replay in football
thread.title_full: Upon further review, it's time to ditch video replay in football

author: freep.com
title: Upon further review, it's time to ditch video replay in football
text:
MORE EAST LANSING – Video replay has turned everybody into a referee.
Even worse, it has turned too many into conspiracy theorists seeking an explanation when the replay doesn't validate what they deem as "obvious" calls.
As I stood waiting for an elevator at Spartan Stadium Saturday evening, a soft-spoken, grandmotherly woman asked me about what she thought were bad calls against Michigan State. She actually wondered if there was an orchestrated "fix" on the game.
She even used the word "fix" in describing her concern.
And Michigan State won by 26 points.
The official video review needs to go. While correcting and clarifying some calls, it isn't helping. It's not improving the overall quality of the product.
Even with replay, game officiating remains interpretative at the moment of the call. What's really a catch? What's really targeting at the head? And replay can only work within the framework of that first interpretation.
Video review was foolishly sold as a corrective panacea. Instead, it has only made the situation worse in both college football as well as the NFL.
It's made referees lazier, thinking they don't need to perform their jobs better because the replay eye upstairs is there to bail them out. It's given coaches and players convenient excuses for overlooking their own accountability in not executing enough winning plays over the course of a 60-minute game. And it's made fans even more paranoid that there are sinister forces lurking in smoke-filled rooms hell-bent on deliberately making bad calls against their beloved teams.
Enough.
If ignorance offered more sanity, then football's better off without video replay.
Make the game officials full-time employees. Train them better. Push them harder. Demand more consistency. Hold them to a higher level of accountability for their mistakes.
But video replay isn't making their job any easier — as evidenced by the deafening cascade of boos from the Spartan Stadium crowd Saturday after some questionable calls against the Hoosiers.
Michigan State thought it had a fourth-quarter fumble recovery when the Indiana receiver spun free, regained his balance and kept running. He wasn't down. The ball got stripped loose. Every TV replay as well as the stadium video board confirmed that. But the referee ruled that forward progress already stopped.
The formula hasn't changed since the first football game ever played. Teams must play through the officiating. And sometimes play above it.
The Big Ten does a better job than most conferences in monitoring its officiating. It has openly acknowledged errors. It publicly reprimanded the officiating crew that wrongly cost Illinois an extra down in a game earlier.
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Sharp: Tired, hurt, MSU relies on resolve, Connor Cook
As a partner in the Collegiate Officiating Consortium, the Big Ten's attempting to create more transparency.
In August, the conference acknowledged that it screwed up two first-half plays in last season's Ohio State-Penn State game. An Ohio State interception counted when TV replays as well as the Beaver Stadium video board clearly showed that it should've been an incomplete pass. There was a technical snafu in the video review booth at the stadium that prevented the crew from getting every available camera angle.
As a result, the Big Ten promptly gave replay officials access to a mute feed of the TV broadcast as a failsafe.
Which begs the question: Why didn't it consider that before?
The officials also failed to notice that the play clock expired before the Buckeyes kicked a 49-yard field goal.
And — for some reason — such situations aren't subject to video review.
Ohio State beat Penn State in double overtime. A loss in the game would've denied the Buckeyes a berth in the inaugural College Football Playoff.
The overall quality of officiating isn't any worse now than it was five, 10 or 20 years ago. Mistakes happen. Human error is always involved in every element of sports. But the expectation of perfection through video has only further magnified the imperfections.
